Description: Egyptian terracotta figure of bearded man wearing a cap. In ‘grotesque’ style, with a receeding hairline, and prominent nose. Mould-made and solid. Traces of white coating and pink paint (?). Dark red-brown Nile silt fabric with grey core, abundant mica, quartz, organics and white inclusions. Head only.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Probably made in Naukratis. Three similar examples of bearded figures from Naukratis, but with pointed caps (Cambridge, Museum of Classical Archaeology NA703; Oxford, Ashmolean Museum AN1896-1908-E.4722 and in an earlier style, but of the same subject AN1886.486) with late 4th to 3rd century BC parallels (Memphis, Petrie 1909a, pl. 42, no. 55; Tell Atrib Szymańska 2005, no. 174; Bayer Niemeier 1988, no.468). However the style is more consistent with the various 'grotesque' devotee and dancer figures found at Naukratis and of 3rd to 2nd or 1st century Bc date. Bayer Niemeier , E. 1988, Bildwerke der Sammlung Kaufmann / Liebieghaus Museum Alter Plastik Frankfurt am Main I. Griechisch- römische Terrakotten, Melsungen. Petrie, W.M.Fl. 1909, Memphis I, London. Szymańska, H. 2005, Terres cuites d’Athribis, Turnhout.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.496) (Phase 3)
